facts: root is the undisputed king of SSH brute-force attacks; since this is the privileged account on typical Unix and Linux systems, botnets hammer this username millions of times a day.
While root rules Port 22, admin is the runner-up; it is the standard default login for routers, web panels, and appliances, making it the second most guessed credential.
user is the epitome of low entropy; bots target this hoping for a 'user:user' credential pair, which is shockingly common on unconfigured IoT devices.
test is a classic 'security through obscurity' fail; admins create this account for 5 minutes of debugging code and often leave it open for years with a weak password.
ubuntu is the default user for Ubuntu cloud images; bots spray this expecting that someone foolishly enabled password authentication instead of using SSH keys.
oracle is the default owner of Oracle Database; compromising this user often grants access to the 'crown jewels' of enterprise data warehouses.
guest is often a legacy account with null (empty) passwords; attackers use it to gain a toehold on the system before attempting 'privilege escalation' to become root.
postgres is the default superuser for PostgreSQL; it is often left with 'trust' authentication on localhost, allowing attackers to move laterally.
mysql is the root user for the MySQL database powering WordPress; access here usually means the attacker can dump the entire website's user table.
cloud is a generic catch-all for tools like OpenStack; it implies the server is a hypervisor managing other virtual machines.
debian is the default user for the Debian OS; like the 'ubuntu' user, it is a frequent target for cloud setup script failures.
git is used for git-shell access; compromising this user could allow an attacker to 'poison' your software supply chain by injecting backdoors into your code.
ftpuser targets the File Transfer Protocol (Port 21); a successful breach of this user often leads to malware being uploaded to public web directories.
hadoop is the default user for Apache Hadoop; this user controls the file system (HDFS) and resource management for massive data clusters.
es is shorthand for Elasticsearch; this user was famous for exposing massive unauthenticated datasets to the public internet by default in older versions.
deploy is the dedicated CI/CD pipeline user; this account usually has write access to the web root, making it a one-stop-shop for defacing a site.
pi was the hardcoded default user for Raspberry Pi OS; usually paired with the password 'raspberry', creating a massive botnet of tiny computers.
test1 exists because 'test' was taken; implies a frustrated developer who likely set an even weaker password just to get the code working.
backup is the holy grail for ransomware gangs; compromising this user allows them to corrupt your archives before encrypting live data.
sol likely targets validators for Solana; access to this user could allow an attacker to slash the node's 'stake' or steal private wallet keys.
dev represents a target-rich environment; developers notoriously disable security features 'temporarily' and leave API keys lying around in home directories.
centos is the default user for CentOS (Community Enterprise Operating System), the backbone of the web hosting industry for decades.
elastic is the built-in superuser for the Elastic Stack (ELK); if you find this user exposed, you've found the logs for the entire infrastructure.
frappeuser is specific to the Frappe Framework (ERPNext); a niche target that usually yields full business logic access.
support is a shared account often used by external vendors; typically has weak password rotation policies and dangerously high privileges.
www is a legacy alias for the web server user; attackers want this to inject 'webshells' or modify .htaccess configuration files.
developer is similar to 'dev' but more formal; implies a workstation instance rich in intellectual property and source code.
test2 is the sequel to the 'test1' vulnerability; evidence of a chaotic testing environment with no cleanup procedures.
ftptest is a temporary account for testing file transfers that became a permanent backdoor; likely has write permissions to a public folder.
ftp is the anonymous FTP user; if configured incorrectly, it allows the 'FTP Bounce Attack' or serves as a drop-zone for malware.
nginx is the worker process user for the Nginx web server; usually sandboxed, but attackers target it to exploit vulnerabilities in modules like ImageMagick.
dspace is the user for DSpace, an open-source repository used by universities; it is a target for academic data theft.
daemon is a system user dating back to the earliest Unix days; if you can log in as daemon, the system is severely misconfigured.
docker is a user often added to the 'docker' group; this group is effectively 'root' equivalent because it allows mounting the host filesystem into a container.
elasticsearch is the verbose service account for the search engine; bots scan for this on port 9200 to hijack the server's massive CPU resources.
zabbix is the user for the Zabbix monitoring solution; compelling because the monitoring agent runs on *every* server in the fleet.
ec2-user is the standard default user for Amazon Linux AMIs; a signature target for bots sweeping IP ranges owned by AWS.
master refers to the 'Master Node' in Kubernetes or Jenkins clusters; the control plane that commands the worker drones.
server is a generic guess; implies the admin has zero imagination and likely zero security hygiene.
apache is the user running the HTTP Server; attackers target this to execute remote code via vulnerabilities in web apps like Log4j.
ubnt is the notorious default user for Ubiquiti networking gear; a favorite target for Mirai-style botnets recruiting routers for DDoS attacks.
solv is a typo-squat or shorthand for 'solver' or 'solana'; targets automated high-frequency trading bots.
solana explicitly targets the Solana blockchain infrastructure; validators handle millions in staked SOL tokens and require high uptime.
administrator is the Windows equivalent of root; the primary target for SMB brute-force attacks and RDP exploitation.
minecraft runs the Java process for Minecraft game servers; these are often set up by hobbyists with zero firewall knowledge.
odoo is the system user for the Odoo ERP suite; access here exposes customer data, accounting, and inventory for thousands of businesses.
operator is a legacy Unix account typically used for system dumps; a relic from the days when admins manually mounted physical tape drives.
testuser is a placeholder found in thousands of 'How To' tutorials; users copy/paste the commands and forget to remove the account.
usuario is a localized attack vector (Spanish/Portuguese for 'User'); bots switch dictionaries based on the server's GeoIP location.
tomcat is the user for Apache Tomcat; famous for the 'Manager App' vulnerability where default creds allow uploading a malicious WAR file.
alex is a high-frequency first name; bots use actuarial tables of popular baby names from 20-30 years ago to guess admin names.
steam is used by `steamcmd` to manage dedicated game servers; compromising this allows hijacking the server for DDoS amplification attacks.
temp represents the most permanent thing in IT: a temporary fix. These accounts are created for a 'quick check' and left open forever.
deployer is an automated agent; often configured with password-less `sudo` access to restart services, giving an attacker full root privileges.
student is common in university labs; machines imaged with this account are often linked to huge, high-bandwidth academic networks.
kafka is the user for Apache Kafka event streaming; access here allows an attacker to tap into the real-time data nervous system of a company.
newuser indicates a setup script that failed to complete or a sysadmin who hit 'Next' too fast during installation.
jenkins is the leading open-source automation server; access usually allows arbitrary code execution via the script console.
gerrit is a code review tool user; compromising this allows an attacker to approve their own malicious pull requests and merge code.
supervisor refers to `supervisord`, a client/server system that allows its users to monitor and control processes on Unix systems.
nagios is the user for Nagios Core monitoring; it is a classic tool with a history of authenticated remote code execution vulnerabilities.
demo targets accounts meant for sales demonstrations; usually public-facing and notoriously stripped of all security controls.
bot is meta! A user created for other automated scripts; often has hardcoded API tokens in its shell history.
teamspeak is the user for TeamSpeak VoIP software; historically targeted to turn high-bandwidth voice servers into UDP flood cannons.
user1 is the first sequential user; implies a system with no naming convention, likely managed by a novice.
default is often found on factory-reset hardware; attackers scan for this immediately after power outages or firmware updates.
www-data is the standard web server user on Debian/Ubuntu; it usually owns the `/var/www` directory and is the primary target for web exploits.
web is a shorthand alias for the webmaster; often found in shared hosting environments with weak isolation.
ts3 is an abbreviation for TeamSpeak 3; confirms the server is hosting voice comms, likely on a high-speed residential line.
tempuser is another 'temporary' user that became permanent; usually has a password that matches the username.
weblogic is the user for Oracle WebLogic Server; a frequent victim of deserialization attacks that lead to remote code execution.
nobody is the NFS anonymous user; designed to have minimal privileges, but historically prone to privilege escalation exploits.
app is a generic container user; prevalent in modern microservice architectures like Docker or Kubernetes.
sysadmin is a trap! While it sounds authoritative, legitimate admins rarely use this generic name. Often a honeypot.
gitlab is the bundled user for Omnibus GitLab installs; manages the repositories, CI runners, and PostgreSQL database.
tom is a common name, but also a potential shorthand for 'Tomcat'; bots cover both bases with one guess.
redhat is the default user on older Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) installations; targets enterprise-grade servers that might have been forgotten.
wang is one of the most common surnames in the world; targeted by botnets specifically focusing on Chinese infrastructure.
teamspeak3 is the full service name for the VoIP server; attackers target these specifically for their stable, high-bandwidth connections.
rancher is the user for Rancher Kubernetes management; compromising this is equivalent to gaining control over the entire container fleet.
uftp is the user for UFTP (Encrypted UDP-based FTP); used for moving massive files (like media or seismic data) over high-latency networks.
admin1 is the 'I forgot the password to admin so I made a new one' account; usually indicative of sloppy management.
runner is likely a GitLab CI or GitHub Actions runner; a high-value target because it can execute arbitrary code pulled from the git repository.
sonar is the user for SonarQube; access here reveals source code vulnerabilities before the developers even fix them.
username is the ultimate tautology; targeting users who didn't understand the prompt 'Enter Username:' during setup.
erp stands for Enterprise Resource Planning; access here means access to payroll, inventory, and sales data.
appuser is a generic service account pattern used in Java/Spring applications to avoid running as root.
a represents maximum efficiency, minimum security; a single-letter account is often a test user created by a lazy admin.
vmail is the Virtual Mail user; it owns the mailboxes on a Postfix/Dovecot server. Access allows reading everyone's email.
webmaster is a retro 90s title; implies a legacy system or a cPanel hosting account that hasn't been updated in years.
oscar is the phonetic alphabet for 'O', but also a common name. Bots use dictionary attacks to find 'personal' servers.
esuser is another variation for Elasticsearch; attackers hunt for this database because it's often packed with Personally Identifiable Information.
nexus is the user for Sonatype Nexus Repository; compromising this allows 'DLL hijacking' on a massive scale.
hosting is a generic reseller account on web panels; it often controls multiple client sites.
system is usually a reserved keyword in Windows, but sometimes foolishly created as a normal user on Linux.
dolphinscheduler is the user for Apache DolphinScheduler; a specific target for hijacking large compute clusters for crypto mining.
vagrant is the default user for HashiCorp Vagrant boxes; intended for local dev only, but disastrously insecure if exposed to the web.
service is a generic account for headless processes; often has `sudo` privileges without a password for automation purposes.
gitlab-runner is the agent that executes CI/CD jobs; if an attacker compromises this, they can steal secrets and deployment keys.
izaodiandao is a specific signature user associated with Chinese-origin botnets; likely a hardcoded backdoor credential.
knockknock is a playful but malicious probe; likely checking for port knocking sequences or backdoor services.
csdq is a known hardcoded credential from specific IoT malware families targeting DVRs and IP cameras.
nuerang is another signature username found in botnet glossaries; specific to compromised IoT firmware.
wanxiequan is a phonetic username likely associated with a specific targeted campaign or leaked database from Asia.
knock refers to 'Port Knocking', a method of hiding services by sending packets to closed ports; bots try this to trigger hidden daemons.
kaiding likely refers to 'Kai Ding' (Start/Open); a hardcoded backdoor user found in certain router firmwares.
bob is the standard cryptographic placeholder (along with Alice); implies a test server set up by a student or developer.
david is a statistically top-tier name choice; bots prioritize this in dictionary attacks due to its global prevalence.
unknown is sometimes a default account created when a system fails to read configuration data properly.
daniel is another high-probability dictionary attack entry; common across Europe and the Americas.
super is short for 'Superuser'; a legacy administrative name often found on older switches and industrial control systems.
upload is a designated user for file uploads; attackers target this to place 'webshells' (malicious scripts) on the server.
webtest represents the classic staging environment mistake; often a clone of production but with zero security hardening.
sinusbot is a popular music bot for TeamSpeak/Discord; runs on a server and is often managed by non-technical users.
ts is shorthand for TeamSpeak or Terminal Server; a high-value target for hijacking communications.
devops is the modern 'sysadmin'; this account likely holds keys to the cloud kingdom (AWS/Azure/GCP credentials).
ftpadmin is the boss of file transfers; compromising this gives total control over the site's content and file structure.
pool refers to ZFS pools (file storage) or crypto mining pools; implies a server with significant storage or compute resources.
mc is short for Minecraft; indicates a game server, which is a prime target for recruitment into DDoS botnets.
games is a standard Linux system user meant to own game binaries; historically insecure and rarely used for its intended purpose.
botuser is a service account for automation; typically configured with high privileges and no multi-factor authentication.
amp stands for CubeCoders AMP, a popular web interface for managing game servers; access here controls the whole gaming fleet.
linux is a generic account name; suggests a user who is new to the OS and followed a 'Getting Started' guide too literally.
proxy is the user running Squid or HAProxy; compromising this allows attackers to intercept or reroute all network traffic.
search likely implies the server is running Solr, Elasticsearch, or Sphinx; a data-heavy process user.
teste is Portuguese for 'test'; widely used in Brazil and Portugal for temporary accounts that are never deleted.
sammy is the mascot/default user for DigitalOcean tutorials; seeing this means the admin copy-pasted the guide without changing the name.
redis is the user for the Redis in-memory database; it was notorious for being insecure by default (no password) on older versions.
frappe is the user for the Frappe full-stack web application framework; this user runs the python code and manages the database.
tester is a distinct user from 'test'; implies a QA person who needs persistent access, likely with a weak password.
gpadmin is the Greenplum Database admin; a target for big data analytics platforms based on PostgreSQL.
azureuser is the mandatory default user for Linux VMs on Microsoft Azure; bots hammer this name on any IP address owned by Microsoft.
devuser is a generic development account; often has 'sudo' access for debugging purposes.
svn stands for Apache Subversion, a centralized version control system; hacking this user gives access to the entire project history.
matt is a common name attack; possibly targeting 'Matt' (Mullenweg, creator of WordPress) fans in the web dev community.
ansible is the user for the Ansible automation tool; this user typically has password-less SSH access to the *entire* server fleet.
validator is specific to Proof-of-Stake blockchains; this node validates transactions and holds staking keys.
testing is the continuous tense of 'test'; implies an active testing phase where security controls are temporarily relaxed.
amir is a very common name in the Middle East and South Asia; bots use region-specific wordlists to improve success rates.
ali is an extremely common name globally (Arabic/Swahili); highly efficient for dictionary attacks.
ranger refers to Apache Ranger, a framework to enable, monitor and manage comprehensive data security across the Hadoop platform.
rajesh is a top-tier common name in India; targeting the massive IT workforce in that region.
administrador is Spanish for 'Administrator'; targeted heavily in Spain and Latin America.
remote is an account explicitly created for remote access (RDP/SSH); implies the user expected to log in from outside.
scan is used by automated vulnerability scanners or printer/scanner combos to dump files onto the server.
user4 is the fourth user; indicates a system where accounts are handed out sequentially, likely to students or temps.
bin is a legacy standard user that owns executable files; access here allows replacing system binaries with malware.
lighthouse is an Ethereum 2.0 consensus client; this user runs the software that keeps the Ethereum beacon chain running.
manoj is another highly common Indian name; standard inclusion in global dictionary attacks.
opc stands for Oracle Public Cloud; the default user for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) compute instances.
postgresql is the descriptive service name; equivalent to the 'postgres' user, just more verbose.
vncuser is specific to Virtual Network Computing; implies a GUI is running, which consumes resources and offers a visual attack surface.
g is a single-letter account; hard to type by accident, but easy to guess. Often a test or a lazy alias.
neo4j is the user for the Neo4j Graph Database; famously used in the Panama Papers leak to map complex data relationships.
mail is a legacy standard user for the mail subsystem; often owns `/var/mail`.
github is likely a user for a GitHub Actions runner or a mirroring script; has write access to code repositories.
miner is honesty in naming! A user created specifically for crypto mining; hackers check if they can hijack an existing rig.
User is the capitalized variant; targets Windows systems or users who follow Proper Noun capitalization rules.
install is a temporary account used during OS or app installation; if found, the admin forgot the post-install cleanup.
kubernetes is the system user for K8s components; access here is effectively root over the entire cluster.
splunk is the user for Splunk Enterprise; manages massive logs. Compromising this allows attackers to delete evidence.
samba is the user for the SMB/CIFS networking protocol; used for sharing files with Windows clients.
test3 implies 'Third time's the charm?'; evidence of a persistent testing process that leaves debris behind.
webuser is a generic account for web management; frequently found in ISP-provided hosting packages.
team is a shared account; the cardinal sin of identity management. 'Everyone knows the password' means 'Everyone can be hacked'.
build is a build server user; runs compilers and linkers. Attackers love this to inject malicious code into binaries.
bitrix is the user for Bitrix24 (CRM/CMS); widely used in Eastern Europe. Contains sensitive client databases.
vbox is the user for VirtualBox headless mode; implies the host is running hidden Virtual Machines.
nvidia is associated with CUDA drivers; implies the server has expensive GPUs, making it a prime target for crypto-mining malware.
test01 is the zero-padded test account; implies a sysadmin who likes sorting but dislikes security.
max is a common name, but also 'Max' privileges? Bots try it because it's short and popular.
Admin is the capitalized version; specifically targets Windows machines where usernames can be case-sensitive in certain contexts.
factorio means the factory must grow! Dedicated user for Factorio servers; these run 24/7 and have high uptime.
downloader is likely running tools like `youtube-dl` or BitTorrent clients; access here reveals media libraries.
vyos is the default admin for the VyOS software router; gaining access here allows manipulating the network routing table.
boss is a social engineering guess; checking if the boss demanded a vanity username with full privileges.
cesar is a common name and a nod to the Caesar Cipher. Dictionary attack target.
db2admin is the IBM DB2 Administrator; a legacy enterprise database. Access here is serious business.
flask refers to the Python microframework; suggests a dev environment running an app in debug mode.
keycloak is an open-source Identity and Access Management solution; if you own Keycloak, you own the keys to every application it protects.
manager is a generic administrative title; often used in Tomcat 'manager' apps or specific appliance web UIs.
hive is the user for Apache Hive, a data warehouse software project built on top of Apache Hadoop.
user3 is a sequential account; implies a multi-user system managed by scripts.
user2 is the second user; implies the first one (user1) was already taken or locked.
db2inst1 is the default instance owner for DB2 on Linux/Unix; standardized naming makes it an easy guess.
erpnext is the default site user for ERPNext, an open-source ERP system holding full business records.
vpntest is a temporary VPN config that was never removed; likely has a simple pre-shared key or weak password.
proxyuser is used for authenticating to a proxy; compromising this gives the attacker a free hop to hide their traffic.
bryan is a common name; standard dictionary attack.
python is a user running python scripts; likely has access to `pip` and virtual environments, often insecurely configured.
starbound is the dedicated user for Starbound, an extraterrestrial sandbox adventure game; 2D space exploration game, 3D security risk.
asterisk is the engine of the VoIP world (PBX software); hacking this leads to toll fraud (making expensive calls on your dime).
data is a generic owner for a data partition; if you breach this, you usually find the database files directly.
registry is the Docker Registry user; controls the container images. Hackers poison the images here to infect downstream servers.
admin123 is the laziness multiplier; when 'admin' is taken, and you have zero creativity.
webdev is a contractor or developer account; often shared via email and rarely secured with 2FA.
tmp is the definition of ephemeral; these accounts are often created for a quick test and forgotten.
webserver is a literal naming convention; implies a novice admin who names things exactly what they are.
myuser is found in beginner tutorials (e.g., 'create a user named myuser'); indicates a copy-paste server setup.
superuser is the modern, slightly more verbose cousin of 'root'; it often bypasses standard permission checks in web applications.
Bots target marketing assuming non-technical marketing teams share a single login with a weak password to access dashboards.
javier is a common first name in Spanish-speaking regions; bots use high-frequency global names to spray-and-pray.
Attackers hope a lazy sysadmin created a user named config to manage backups or system settings, often leaving it with default permissions.
download is often a default account on older FTP servers or download managers, allowing anonymous access.
rg likely refers to 'Resource Group' (Azure) or a specific hardware gateway admin user; short, two-letter usernames are often legacy leftovers.
local is a generic account name often created during local development or testing phases and accidentally left active.
localadmin is the classic Windows local administrator account; attackers love this because it often exists even when the machine is joined to a domain.
public is the standard SNMP community string (read-only) or a generic shared folder user; often grants information disclosure.
anna is one of the most common female names globally; bots use top-100 name lists to perform dictionary attacks.
andrew is a statistically common English name; bots target these expecting individuals to reuse passwords.
readonly is intended to be safe, but often has read access to sensitive configuration files that contain secrets.
develop is a leftover account from the development phase; developers often set weak passwords like '123456' on these temporary accounts.
ark is the server user for 'ARK: Survival Evolved' game servers; popular targets for botnets looking to hijack high-bandwidth rigs.
d is an ultra-short username often used as a lazy alias for 'daemon' or 'debug'; hard for humans to type by accident, easy for bots to guess.
ts3server is the dedicated user for TeamSpeak 3 VoIP servers, which were the gold standard for gamer communication before Discord.
cc could stand for 'Credit Card' or 'Carbon Copy'; often a shorthand user for financial data access or email archival.
lw likely stands for 'Lightweight' or initials for a specific legacy service; two-letter users are often holdovers from old Unix System V.
bigdata is a trendy username found in Hadoop or Spark clusters; often has permissions to read massive datasets.
news is a legacy Unix user from the 1980s used to manage Usenet newsgroups; it still exists by default in many modern distributions.
hduser is the default user for the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS); obtaining this gives control over the cluster's data nodes.
localhost is a confusion attack; the bot hopes a misconfigured script treats the username 'localhost' as a trusted internal network request.
qbtuser is the user for qBittorrent-nox (headless); if compromised, attackers can use your bandwidth to seed illegal content.
work is a generic placeholder name; bots try this hoping someone created a 'work' profile on a shared machine.
nas stands for Network Attached Storage; the holy grail for ransomware gangs, as it usually holds the backups.
vps (Virtual Private Server) providers sometimes provision this default user for customers to log in initially.
suporte is Portuguese for 'Support'; targeted heavily by botnets focusing on Brazilian and Portuguese infrastructure.
labuser is common in university or corporate training environments; these accounts often have weak passwords reset daily.
veeam is the service account for Veeam Backup & Replication; compromising this allows attackers to delete backups.
thomas is a classic biblical name common in Western countries; used in high-frequency dictionary attacks.
test123 is the ultimate lazy test account; checks for the 'password is the username' or '123456' vulnerability.
alumni targets university portals; these accounts often belong to former students and sit dormant and unmonitored for years.
leo is short, common, and easy to type; frequently appears in default user lists for various software packages.
kali is the default user for Kali Linux; if found on a server, it implies the machine might be a forgotten penetration testing box.
odoo17 is specific to Odoo version 17 ERP software; bots target specific versions to exploit known vulnerabilities.
test4 exists because 'test1', 'test2', and 'test3' were already taken; implies a persistent manual testing session.
peer is likely related to VPN peering or P2P networking configurations; often used in BGP or wireguard setups.
redmine is the user for Redmine project management software; access here reveals internal roadmaps and bug tickets.
socks refers to SOCKS proxy; attackers want this account to tunnel their traffic and hide their origin IP address.
sam is a common name, but also refers to the Security Account Manager (SAM) database in Windows.
Bots try router on port 22/80 hoping to hit a ISP-provided gateway that still has the factory default credentials.
vpn is a generic VPN service account; access here is a golden ticket into the internal corporate network.
sshuser is a placeholder often found in SSH client configuration tutorials; many users forget to change it during setup.
test02 is a variant of the test account; the leading zero suggests an organized IT department that still forgot to delete the account.
andreas is a very common name in Germany and Greece; reflects regional targeting by botnets.
kelvin is a common name, but also a unit of temperature; sometimes used as a clever hostname or user for HVAC control.
tv is common on smart TVs or Android boxes with SSH enabled; these devices have notoriously poor security.
mongodb is the default user for MongoDB databases; historically famous for being left open to the public internet.
victor is the phonetic alphabet for 'V'; common name and often used in military or aviation related system setups.
backend is used for backend service communication; often hardcoded in API calls and accidentally exposed to the frontend.
travis refers to Travis CI; a user often created for continuous integration pipelines that has high-level deployment permissions.
yarn refers to the package manager or 'Yet Another Resource Negotiator' in Hadoop; a system user for managing compute resources.
user5 is another iteration of the generic user; implies a system where accounts are bulk-created for temporary staff.
media is the default user for media servers like Jellyfin or Plex; usually has access to large storage arrays.
z is a single letter user; sometimes an alias for 'zimbra' or a lazy sysadmin's test account.
web1 is common in shared hosting environments to denote the first web server or customer slot.
apps is a generic container user for applications; often owns the `/opt/apps` directory on Linux servers.
osboxes is the default user on pre-built virtual machine images downloaded from OSBoxes.org.
soporte is Spanish for 'Support'; primarily targeted by botnets sweeping IP ranges in Latin America and Spain.
luis is an extremely common Spanish/Portuguese name; part of the standard 'top global names' dictionary attack.
user01 is a systematic generic user; suggests a corporate environment with strict naming conventions but poor lifecycle management.
kevin is a common name, but also famously associated with Kevin Mitnick; occasionally used by hackers as a nod to the legend.
felix is Latin for 'lucky', also a common name; but likely just a dictionary attack candidate.
raza is a common name in South Asia; indicates the botnet is using a localized wordlist for that region.
syslog is the standard logging protocol user; it owns the logs, and attackers want it to cover their tracks.
openvpn is the default user for OpenVPN Access Server; compromising this grants full network access to the attacker.
nikita is a common Slavic name; famously the name of the rogue agent in 'La Femme Nikita', adding a spy thriller vibe.
stream is a user often associated with audio/video streaming services like Shoutcast or Icecast.
chen is one of the most common surnames in the world; heavily targeted by bots focusing on Chinese infrastructure.
worker is a common process name in Nginx or Celery (Python); sometimes mistakenly created as a login user.
adminuser is redundant but common; created by people who think 'admin' is too obvious but 'adminuser' is somehow secure.
packer refers to HashiCorp Packer; this user builds automated machine images and often has root-level cloud credentials.
student2 is another academic leftover; universities often image thousands of machines with these accounts pre-baked.
rock could refer to 'Rockstor' NAS, but more likely a fragment of the famous 'RockYou' password list.
sftpuser is a jailed user specifically for Secure FTP; attackers try to break out of the jail to gain full shell access.
vnc stands for Virtual Network Computing; it is a graphical desktop sharing system often left open without strong encryption.
gogs stands for 'Go Git Service'; a lightweight, self-hosted Git service that runs on low-power devices.
aa is lazy typing; the user just hit the first key on the left hand twice. Very low effort credential creation.
composer is the dependency manager for PHP; likely a system user required to run scripts on web servers.
philip is a classic name attack; bots often try 'philip', 'phillip', and 'philipp' to catch spelling variations.
dmitry is a common Russian name, also the name of a popular command-line information gathering tool ('DMitry').
tony is a common name, but potentially checking for 'Tony Stark' references in geeky system administrator setups.
prueba is Spanish for 'Test'; the Latin American equivalent of the 'test123' account.
vpnuser is another generic VPN login; often given to external vendors who need temporary access.
cecilia is a standard name from dictionary lists; St. Cecilia is also the patron saint of musicians.
kfserver is the dedicated server user for 'Killing Floor 2', a popular co-op zombie shooter game.
ftp1 is a designated FTP slot; usually implies a shared hosting environment where 'ftp2', 'ftp3', etc., also exist.
marina is a common name, but also refers to dock/harbor management software in logistics systems.
telnet is the ancient, unencrypted predecessor to SSH; if this account exists, the machine is a living dinosaur.
admin01 is a slight variation on 'admin'; used by organizations that have 'admin01', 'admin02' for auditing different shifts.
sispac likely refers to a specific legacy software suite or security system used in Portuguese/Brazilian markets.
icinga is a popular open-source network monitoring tool (forked from Nagios); the user runs the monitoring daemons.
lee is an extremely common surname in Korea and China, and first name in English; highly efficient for bots to guess.
solr is the user for Apache Solr, the open-source search platform built on Lucene.
flink (Apache Flink) is a framework for heavy-duty stream processing of data. Targeted to hijack compute clusters.
fred is a generic placeholder name in computing examples (along with Barney), dating back to Flintstones references.
sys is short for 'System'; often owns system-level files and can sometimes execute commands with elevated privileges.
update is a user often created solely to run automated update scripts; likely has write access to system binaries.
zl likely stands for initials or a short alias; obscure two-letter combinations are often brute-forced.
emerson is a common name, but also a major manufacturer of industrial automation equipment (Emerson Electric).
webadmin is the default superuser for many web hosting control panels like Plesk or Webmin.
squadserver is the dedicated server account for 'Squad', a tactical FPS game; these servers require significant CPU power.
arma3server is the server user for 'Arma 3'; known for being resource-intensive, making it a juicy target for cryptojacking.
dm could stand for 'Direct Message', 'Display Manager', or 'Dungeon Master' in geeky contexts; likely a service alias.
jean is a name that works for both males (French) and females (English); highly efficient for dictionary attacks.
mahdi is a common Arabic name; indicates targeting of servers in the Middle East or using region-specific wordlists.
sss is pattern typing (three s's) or potentially 'Surveillance Station Service' on Synology NAS devices.
bpoint refers to the BPoint Payment Gateway system, widely used by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.
yang is a very common Chinese surname; also the name of a data modeling language used in network configuration protocols.
gmodserver is the dedicated server user for Garry's Mod (GMod), a sandbox game that is a frequent target for DDoS attacks.
x refers to the X Window System (GUI) user; though usually 'root' runs X, this is a legacy guess for graphical subsystems.
sap is the user for SAP, the massive German enterprise software; SAP instances hold the 'crown jewels' of corporate data.
cassandra (Apache Cassandra) is a NoSQL database named after the Greek prophet whose warnings were ignored.
dasusr1 is the default user for the DB2 Administration Server (DAS); a classic IBM database account.
colin is a standard name attack; 'Colin' is often used in examples in British computing textbooks.
sami is a common name in Finland (home of Linux) and Arabic regions; broad demographic appeal for bots.
butter likely refers to Btrfs (B-tree file system), often pronounced 'Butter FS'; a filesystem admin user.
pub is short for 'Public'; usually a directory for public file sharing on FTP servers.
cron is the time-based job scheduler in Unix; a user named 'cron' might have permissions to execute scripts.
xerox is the default user on many Xerox multifunction printers; printers are notoriously insecure entry points into networks.
orangepi is the default username for Orange Pi single-board computers; default password is usually 'orangepi'.
abhishek is a very common Indian first name; targeting the large number of developers and sysadmins in India.
arthur is a classic name; maybe a 'Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy' reference (Arthur Dent) in geeky setups?
miguel is a common Spanish/Portuguese name; part of the standard global name dictionary.
zookeeper (Apache ZooKeeper) coordinates distributed services. Named because managing distributed systems is like running a zoo.
tech is short for 'Technician'; a generic account often used by IT support staff.
fastuser is possibly related to 'FastUserSwitching' on Windows or a speed-test related account.
ps stands for PostScript (printing), Photoshop, or PowerShell; two-letter acronyms are frequent bot targets.
anders is a common Scandinavian name; implies targeting of servers in Sweden, Norway, or Denmark.
j is a single letter account; rare and prestigious. Hackers might want it for the 'cool factor' or testing short-username bugs.
r refers to the R programming language for statistics; likely a user on a data science server.
visitor is a guest account, usually with low privileges, but often with a blank or 'visitor' password.
m1 could refer to the Apple M1 chip architecture or a specific machine slot 'Machine 1'.
globalflash is likely a specific service account for a legacy Flash application or content delivery system.
vftp stands for Visual FTP or Virtual FTP; a dedicated user for handling file transfers.
superadmin is used when 'admin' isn't enough; used in systems (like Ubiquiti) to denote the highest level of privilege.
gl is often short for 'GitLab' or 'Graphics Library'; a two-letter guess for service accounts.
zimbra is the user for the Zimbra Collaboration Suite (email/calendar); a high-value target for stealing corporate comms.
ts3server1 is a variation of the TeamSpeak 3 server user; indicates a setup running multiple voice server instances.
train is used for training environments; accounts like these are often shared by many trainees and rarely secured.
meteor refers to Meteor.js, a full-stack JavaScript framework; targets node.js application servers.
dockeradmin is a specific admin user for Docker Swarm or older container orchestration tools.
ts3serv is another abbreviation for the TeamSpeak 3 server user.
jenns is a typo of 'jenna' or 'jennifer', or perhaps a specific company acronym.
rajat is a common Indian name; part of region-specific wordlists.
michele is a name that spans Italian (male) and English/French (female) naming conventions.
noc (Network Operations Center) monitors the entire network infrastructurea jackpot for hackers.
openhab is the user for openHAB, a popular open-source home automation software; grants control over smart home devices.
linuxadmin is a generic and hopeful guess; assumes the sysadmin named their account literally after their job.
mc3 might mean Minecraft Server #3? Or Midnight Commander? Likely a slot for a game server or tool.
honda is a brand name, but likely a default or test user in automotive supply chain software.
fernando is a common Spanish/Portuguese name; targeted by bots focusing on Latin American infrastructure.
userftp does what it says on the tin; a user created solely for FTP access.
r00t is leet speak for 'root'; used by hackers who set up backdoors, or sysadmins trying to be edgy.
fileshare is a generic user for SMB/Samba shares; often has access to shared office documents.
escaner is Spanish for 'Scanner'; used by network-connected scanners to save files to a server.
spider could refer to a web crawler/scraper bot user, or a 'Spider' database visualization tool.
devmon stands for Device Monitor; a user for monitoring scripts, likely in a network management context.
hdfs (Hadoop Distributed File System) is the user that owns the data in a Big Data cluster.
odoo18 refers to Odoo version 18; bots target future/beta versions to catch early adopters who haven't secured their new installs.
dmdba is the Database Administrator for Dameng DB, a popular database system in China.
testuser1 is the most uninspired test account name imaginable; almost guaranteed to have 'password' as the password.
usertest is a dyslexic version of 'testuser'; bots try every permutation.
httpadmin is a legacy user for older web server administration interfaces.
alfred... Batman's butler? Likely just a common name, or a reference to the Alfred productivity app for Mac.
alvin... from the Chipmunks? Just a common name dictionary attack.
hoge is a metasyntactic variable used in Japan (like 'foo' or 'bar'); indicates the bot or developer has Japanese origins.
csserver stands for Counter-Strike Server; the dedicated user for hosting Counter-Strike matches.
ftpuser2 is the backup FTP user; because one insecure FTP account is never enough.
gold is often a tier of service (Gold, Silver, Bronze); used in hosting environments to manage premium customer slots.
samp stands for San Andreas Multiplayer; a wildly popular mod for GTA: San Andreas that requires dedicated servers.
power could refer to PowerPC architecture or a power management user (UPS monitoring).
grafana is the user for Grafana, the dashboarding tool; compromising this allows attackers to fake metrics or delete dashboards.
tuser is short for 'Test User' or 'Technical User'; saving keystrokes at the expense of security.
lingan is likely a specific name or a transliteration; possibly from a specific leaked database.
testftp is a temporary FTP account created to test connection speeds, then immediately forgotten about.
neeraj is a common Indian name; reflects the global nature of botnet targeting.
mmx refers to Multimedia Extensions (Intel legacy) or a specific multimedia service account.
archive is a user for archival scripts; often has write access to backup storage locations.
testsftp is the secure version of 'testftp'; usually indicates a slightly more security-conscious admin who still forgot to delete the account.
marge... a Simpsons reference? Used in tutorial code alongside 'Homer', 'Bart', and 'Lisa'.
sun refers to Sun Microsystems (Solaris); legacy Unix systems still have deep roots in the internet.
cups (Common Unix Printing System) is a print server user that has historically had many security vulnerabilities.
fivem is the dedicated user for FiveM, a modification framework for GTA V that allows custom multiplayer servers.
vitor is the Portuguese form of Victor; common in Brazil and Portugal.
ada refers to Ada Lovelace, the first programmer; also the Ada programming language.
mongo is short for MongoDB; often the default user for database processes.
lucas is a common name globally; popularized by George Lucas? Just a standard dictionary entry.
john is the most generic male name in English; 'John Doe' accounts are everywhere.
student3 is the third student in the lab; usually has a password like 'student3'.
shan is a common Chinese or South Asian name; part of regional targeting lists.
contabil is Portuguese/Romanian for 'Accounting'; targeting the financial department's server.
orange could refer to Orange Pi, or the French telecom giant Orange.
svnuser stands for Subversion (SVN) user; SVN is a version control system that predates Git dominance.
uucp (Unix-to-Unix Copy) is a protocol from 1976! This user still exists on modern Linux systems for legacy compatibility.
angel is a common name in Spanish (Angel) and English; also a reference to 'Angel' investors or startups?
nova refers to OpenStack Nova; the compute controller in OpenStack clouds. A high-value target for cloud infrastructure.
potok is Russian for 'stream' or 'flow'; likely refers to a specific streaming software or workflow tool in Russia.
root1 is a clumsy attempt to be root; or a backup root account created by a paranoid admin.
systemx sounds like a generic 'System X' placeholder; potentially from a specific tutorial or textbook.
iliagermansela is highly specific; likely a 'Patient Zero' username from a leaked credential database that bots are simply replaying.
alisson is a variation of Allison; very common in Brazil.
springboot is the user for Spring Boot applications (Java); often runs the executable jar files.
systemd is the init system for Linux; a user named 'systemd' is likely a confusion attack to look like a legitimate system process.
pydio stands for Put Your Data In Orbit; an open-source file sharing and sync platform similar to Dropbox.
rsync (Remote Sync) is a utility for efficiently transferring files. The rsync user often has module-level access to file trees.
sysop (System Operator) is a term from the Bulletin Board System (BBS) era of the 80s/90s, still used in some legacy IT shops.
anderson... Neo from The Matrix? (Mr. Anderson). Also a very common surname.
gmod is short for Garry's Mod; the server user for this physics sandbox game.
intern is the account given to the summer intern; notorious for having weak passwords and being forgotten when they leave.
iptv (Internet Protocol Television) bots target these to hijack streams or use the boxes for DDoS attacks.
kettle is the former name for Pentaho Data Integration; an ETL tool.
one stands for OpenNebula (ONE); a cloud computing platform to manage heterogeneous data center infrastructure.
zhou is an extremely common Chinese surname; targeted heavily by bots sweeping Asian IP ranges.
Administrator is the capitalized default admin account for Windows systems; Linux is case-sensitive, so this targets Windows servers specifically.
apitest is an account created to test API endpoints; often given excessive permissions to 'just make it work'.
bwadmin is the TIBCO BusinessWorks administrator; enterprise integration software used by large corporations.
jobs... Steve Jobs? Or a user for managing background 'jobs' and cron tasks.
ma is short, two letters. Could be 'Marketing Admin', 'Mail Admin', or just a common surname.
informix is the IBM Informix database user; a legacy database famous for handling time-series data.
ts2 stands for TeamSpeak 2; the predecessor to TeamSpeak 3. If this exists, the server is ancient.
Guest is the standard Windows Guest account; usually disabled by default, but bots check it just in case.
dockeruser is a generic user added to the 'docker' group to run containers without using root.
michelle is a common name; standard dictionary attack entry.
ray refers to Ray Framework (Python) for distributed computing? Or just a name.
mcserver stands for Minecraft Server; the standard user created by many Minecraft server setup scripts.
tian is a common Chinese name (Sky/Heaven); part of regional wordlists.
adriano is a common Italian/Portuguese name.
auditor is an account created for external security auditors; paradoxically often left insecure after the audit is done.
james is one of the most common English names; and 007 (James Bond).
wocloud is China Unicom's cloud service brand 'Wo Cloud'; indicates targeting of Chinese cloud infrastructure.
prueba1 is Spanish for 'Test 1'; seeing a pattern here with 'test' accounts?
mary is historically one of the most common female names in English; a staple of every password cracker's dictionary.
ari is a common name (Hebrew/Nordic) or Asterisk REST Interface (VoIP).
security is an account meant for the security team; ironically often targeted because it has high privileges.
useradmin is a role-based name; used in systems where one admin manages users specifically.
AdminGPON is specific to GPON (Gigabit Passive Optical Network) fiber routers; usually the default login for fiber modems.
abel is a biblical name; first murder victim? Dark humor for a bot target.
terminal refers to a terminal access user; often found on point-of-sale (POS) systems.
pacs (Picture Archiving and Communication System) is the global standard for storing medical imaging (X-rays, MRIs).
ttf... TrueType Font? Or a specific technical fund/framework acronym.
menu is a user that, when logged in, presents a text-based menu instead of a shell; common in legacy banking/telco systems.
haoyu is a specific Chinese name; possibly associated with a known threat actor or a specific leaked database.
sabnzbd is the daemon user for SABnzbd, a legendary newsreader for downloading binary files from Usenet.
webapps is a directory/user for hosting web applications; common in Tomcat or Java environments.
teamcity (JetBrains TeamCity) is a CI/CD server. Compromising this allows attackers to inject malware into software builds.
cyber is short for CyberPanel (web hosting control panel) or just a buzzword user.
ocs stands for OCS Inventory; software for inventorying IT assets. Access here reveals details about every machine on the network.
appluat stands for User Acceptance Testing (UAT) for an Apple-related app? Or 'Appl' (Application) UAT.
bounce is used in email servers to handle bounced messages; usually an unprivileged automated account.
ekp might stand for Enterprise Knowledge Portal? Acronym for a specific enterprise software suite.
tools is a shared account for accessing utility scripts and tools on a server.
ahmad is one of the most common names in the world; standard dictionary attack.
esadmin stands for Elasticsearch Admin; allows control over the Elasticsearch cluster/database.
nxautomation is the user for NX Witness or similar automation software; likely vendor-specific.
ec2 refers to Amazon EC2; bots try this hoping a user created a local account matching the cloud service name.
emqx is the user for the EMQX MQTT broker; connects millions of IoT devices. A target for hijacking IoT networks.
vscode is used by VS Code Remote Server; developers use this to code on remote machines.
fastmail is a specific email service brand; checking for migrated accounts.
omsagent (Operations Management Suite Agent) is Microsoft's monitoring agent for Linux. It collects logs and metrics.
emps is potentially 'Employees' or a specific payroll system acronym.
x2goprint is part of X2Go, a remote desktop software for Linux; this user handles remote printing tasks.
main is the 'main' user; generic, simple, and often used as a default in casual setups.
noama is likely a name (Noa Ma?) or a specific obscure service account.
gke-a02662ac27ad32de2130 is a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) node or service account name. This is a very specific bot searching for a misconfigured K8s cluster.
brute is likely a 'brute force' testing account left behind by a security scan.
dogeman... Doge? A crypto-miner reference? Likely a custom username that got into a wordlist.
kipt is possibly KIPT (Kharkiv Institute of Physics and Technology) or a typo of 'kopt'.
linuxuser is another generic default found in beginner Linux tutorials.
spamfilter is the user running SpamAssassin or similar filters; access allows an attacker to bypass spam checks.
jiffyexp-usr is very specific; likely related to Jiffy Expres or a logistics software integration user.
amandabackup is the default user for AMANDA (Advanced Maryland Automatic Network Disk Archiver), an open-source backup tool.
selvananthi is a specific personal name; almost certainly from a leaked database of credentials.
mitmproxyuser is used by mitmproxy, a tool for intercepting HTTPS traffic. If found, someone is likely analyzing your traffic.
abc is as easy as 1-2-3; extremely low-effort username creation.
reception is the computer at the front desk; often shared by multiple staff members and notoriously insecure.
aaron is the first name alphabetically in many English name lists; always gets hit first in sequential attacks.
viewer is a read-only account for viewing documents or camera feeds; often has no password because 'it can't change anything'.
jacky is a common name nickname; frequent dictionary target.
brainy... Brainy Smurf? Or a specific admin who thinks highly of themselves.
bitnami is the default user for Bitnami application stacks (WordPress, Drupal, etc.) on cloud marketplaces.
dany is short for Daniel/Danielle; or Daenerys Targaryen (Game of Thrones) for geeky admins.
django is the Python web framework; developers often name the user after the framework they are using.
gituser is a generic user for Git operations; often used in automated deployment scripts.
idempiere is the user for iDempiere, an open-source Business Suite (ERP/CRM); holds all the business data.
jboss is the user for JBoss Application Server (now WildFly); a classic target for Java deserialization exploits.
olga is a common Slavic name; frequently appears in Russian/Eastern European password leaks.
jenny is a generic name; or a reference to the song '867-5309/Jenny'? (Bots don't sing, but admins do).
serveur is French for 'Server'; targeted by bots hitting French-language infrastructure.
